pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:0.2: The monks’ rules and their analysis
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:0.3: The chapter on offenses entailing confession
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.1: At one time the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in the Bamboo Grove, the squirrel sanctuary.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.2: At that time Venerable Dabba the Mallian assigned the dwellings and designated the meals,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.3: and the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka were only newly ordained.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.4: They had little merit, and they obtained inferior dwellings and meals.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.5: They then complained about Dabba to other monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.6: “Dabba the Mallian assigns dwellings and designates meals based on favoritism.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.7: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.8: “How can the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka complain about Venerable Dabba to other monks?”…
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.9: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.12: “… Foolish men, how can you complain about Dabba to other monks?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.13: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.14: And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.15.1: ‘If a monk complains, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:1.16: In this way the Buddha laid down this training rule for the monks.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.1: Knowing that the Buddha had prohibited complaining, the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka considered other ways of getting the monks to hear about their grievances.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.2: They then criticized Dabba the Mallian in the vicinity of other monks,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.3: “Dabba assigns dwellings and designates meals based on favoritism.”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.4: The monks of few desires complained and criticized them,
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.5: “How can the monks Mettiya and Bhūmajaka criticize Venerable Dabba?”…
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.6: “Is it true, monks, that you do this?”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.9: “… Foolish men, how can you criticize Dabba?
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.10: This won’t give rise to confidence in those without it …
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.11: And so, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:2.12.1: ‘If a monk complains or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession.’”
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.1.2: when someone who is fully ordained is the assigner of dwellings or the designator of meals or the distributor of rice porridge or the distributor of fruit or the distributor of non-staple food or the distributor of small requisites, and he has been agreed upon by the Sangha as such, then if a monk complains about him or criticizes him to one who is fully ordained—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.1.3.1: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, and he complains or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.1.4: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, and he complains or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.1.5: If it is a legitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as illegitimate, and he complains or criticizes, he commits an offense entailing confession.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.1: If he complains or criticizes to one who is not fully ordained, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.2: When someone who is fully ordained is the assigner of dwellings or the designator of meals or the distributor of rice porridge or the distributor of fruit or the distributor of non-staple food or the distributor of small requisites, but he has not been agreed upon by the Sangha as such, then if a monk complains about him or criticizes him to one who is fully ordained or to one who is not fully ordained—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.3: When someone who is not fully ordained is the assigner of dwellings or the designator of meals or the distributor of rice porridge or the distributor of fruit or the distributor of non-staple food or the distributor of small requisites, whether he has been agreed upon by the Sangha as such or not, then if a monk complains about him or criticizes him to one who is fully ordained or to one who is not fully ordained—desiring to disparage him, desiring to give him a bad reputation, desiring to humiliate him—he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.4: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he perceives it as legitimate, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.5: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, but he is unsure of it, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.2.6: If it is an illegitimate legal procedure, and he perceives it as such, he commits an offense of wrong conduct.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.3.2: if he complains about or criticizes one who regularly acts from desire, ill will, confusion, or fear;
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.3.4: if he is the first offender.
pli-tv-bu-vb-pc13:3.3.5: The third rule, the training rule on complaining, is finished.
